title: InteractiveOnlinePaper: A framework for online publications with braingl-web including interactive 2D figures linked with the interactive 3D viewer

text:
Katja Heuer, Ralph Schurade, Angela D. Friederici & Alfred Anwander

Max Planck Institute for Human Cognitive and Brain Sciences, Leipzig, Germany

This is work in progress. We recently included the awesome d3 and three.js libraries and are currently restructuring the code to provide you with a very user-friendly web app and a comprehensive template.
This is a template for an online publication with interactive 3D figures. The code of the template can be found as example-pub at github.com/katjaq/braingl-web.
In addition to such an online article template, braingl-web also provides a framework to create an interactive 3D website for your data which you can easily link with your journal publication.
The code for the template can be found as 'brainnetworks' within braingl-web.
Our following example shows connectivity data generated with a Jupyter notebook from Nilearn and you can easily reproduce the results here

Our template currently provides 2 connectivity diagrams: You can chose between the circular representation and the matrix representation. The matrix gives you the option to sort the data, for instance according to the networks. The order in which the matrix is given in our example has been manually sorted by Gael, the lead developer of Nilearn, in order to create a good example. Thanks to Gael again :D
And here I will have to continue work tomorrow... :D

paragraphs.image_title: Surfing the Connectome: An interactive combined visualization of structural and functional connectivity.
paragraphs.image_text:
Template website at openscience.cbs.mpg.de/brainnetworks.
Transcallosal functional connectivity of the precentral gyrus. The end points on the right motor cortex are rainbow coded and show an asymmetric devision into two functional "bundles".
